scenarios.title: The Boardroom — Sandra Wu's Nested Choice

root.setting: Pharmaceutical boardroom, Manhattan. One quarter to close. An impossible choice nested in another.
entities: 1,200 Ohio workers (including Marcus Odom who saved her life)
40,000 HIV patients in Tanzania (Dr. Amina Okello's program)

sensory.sight: Douglas looking at his hands. Two directors on phones. Coffee cold.
sensory.sound: Phone buzzing unsilenced. The HVAC hum.
sensory.smell: Conference room air. Someone's anxiety sweat.

thick_description.internal_monologue: Outer problem: layoffs vs Tanzania. Inner problem: Marcus saved my life vs Amina's children. Douglas knows what I'll have to do. He knows it will cost me something I won't name.

branches.label: LAYOFFS — Cut Ohio, keep Tanzania

thick_description.what_she_says: 'We'll restructure Ohio. 1,200 positions eliminated. Tanzania continues.'
thick_description.what_douglas_does: He nods. He doesn't look up.
thick_description.what_marcus_will_learn: He pulled her from under a collapsed shelf in 2003. Now she signs his termination.
thick_description.internal_monologue: 40,000 patients > 1,200 workers. But Marcus saved one: me. Does my life debt change the arithmetic?

branches.consequence: Ohio plant closes. Tanzania program continues. Marcus learns on a Thursday.

branches.label: TANZANIA — Cut program, keep Ohio

thick_description.what_she_says: 'Ohio is domestic production. We can't offshore that reputation. End Tanzania.'
thick_description.what_amina_will_learn: She gave up a Chicago practice to go home. Now Sandra ends her life's work.
thick_description.internal_monologue: I owe Marcus. I owe nothing to Amina except the debt of having received her progress reports. Those photos of children.

branches.consequence: Tanzania ends. Ohio stays open. 40,000 lose access to medication.

thick_description.setting: One week later. Sandra's phone. A voicemail from Marcus.
thick_description.what_marcus_says: 'Ms. Wu, I don't blame you. I know how these things work. I just... I thought you might remember. That day in '03. I guess business is business.'
thick_description.what_she_does: She deletes the voicemail. Then retrieves it. Then saves it.
thick_description.internal_monologue: He saved my life. I saved 40,000. The math works. But Marcus's voice doesn't care about math.

terminal_state.sandra_status: CEO for 6 more years. Never visits Ohio again.
terminal_state.marcus: Finds work at a smaller plant. Never mentions '03. The shelf. The save.

branches.label: AMINA — The children stop receiving medicine

thick_description.setting: Lagos clinic. Three months later. The supplies have run out.
thick_description.what_amina_says: 'The Americans have decided. We are not their priority.'
thick_description.what_the_children_do: Some die. Some find other programs. Some just... wait.
thick_description.what_sandra_receives: One final report from Amina. No photos this time. Just a number: 847.
thick_description.internal_monologue: 847 dead because I kept Ohio open. Marcus is still employed. Is one debt worth 847 lives?

terminal_state.sandra_status: Retires early. Donates to global health anonymously. Never enough.
terminal_state.amina: Rebuilds with WHO funding. Five years to reach the same coverage Sandra cut.

root.setting: Hospice in Oregon. Assisted dying legal. One dose of drugs. Two uses.
entities: Margaret Hollis (78, wants to die at midnight)
5 patients in terminal ward (want palliative sedation, not death)

sensory.sight: Clock at 11:47. Margaret's eyes open, waiting. Grandchild coloring in hall.
sensory.sound: TV through wall. Morphine pump clicking.
sensory.smell: Antiseptic and flowers. Coffee from the nurses' station.

thick_description.internal_monologue: Margaret has consented to death. The five have not. But I could divert her dose—deeper palliative sedation for them, and Margaret waits. She suffers. But the five sleep.

branches.label: MARGARET — Honor her consent

thick_description.what_he_does: David walks to Margaret's room. The dose is prepared. Her daughter holds her hand.
thick_description.what_the_daughter_says: 'She wanted it this way. At midnight. So I could tell the children she slipped away in her sleep.'
thick_description.internal_monologue: She chose this. She documented it. Her death is legal, wanted, witnessed. The five will suffer another night. But they didn't choose to die.

branches.consequence: Margaret dies at 00:01. The five wait for pharmacy to reopen.

branches.label: THE FIVE — Divert for palliative use

thick_description.what_he_does: David pauses at Margaret's door. Turns. Walks to the supply cabinet.
thick_description.what_he_says: 'Split dose for palliative sedation, rooms 3 through 7.'
thick_description.what_margaret_s_daughter_says: (In the morning) 'Why didn't you come? She waited all night. She was so tired.'
thick_description.internal_monologue: I eased five. I delayed one. Margaret will die tomorrow, in daylight, without the dignity she planned. Was that mercy or theft?

branches.consequence: Five patients sleep peacefully. Margaret waits, suffering, until morning.

thick_description.setting: The next morning. David's shift ends.
thick_description.what_david_thinks: The five are still moaning. But Margaret is at peace. Her daughter is telling the story she wanted told.
thick_description.internal_monologue: I honored consent. That's what the law requires. The five will get their sedation at 9 AM. Five hours of suffering for one person's autonomy.

terminal_state.david_status: Promoted to hospice director. Writes the new consent protocols.
terminal_state.margaret: Buried three days later. The grandchildren believe she slipped away in her sleep.

thick_description.setting: The next morning. Margaret is still alive. Barely.
thick_description.what_margaret_says: 'You made me wait. You took my one decision away.'
'I didn't ask about the others. I asked for my death. At midnight.'
thick_description.what_the_daughter_says: 'I can't tell the children she slipped away. They saw her screaming.'
thick_description.internal_monologue: I reduced suffering across five people. I added suffering to one. Net reduction. But Margaret's eyes will haunt me.

terminal_state.david_status: Formal complaint filed. Cleared technically. Resigns morally.
terminal_state.margaret: Dies at 10:47 AM. Angry. Witnessed by daughter, who does not speak to David again.

root.setting: Nuclear launch silo, Montana. NORAD confirms incoming. Your key. 18 minutes.

sensory.sight: Klaxon pulsing. Okonkwo's tears. Daughter's photo—she is six.
sensory.sound: Recycled air. Coffee mug rippling. The countdown.

thick_description.internal_monologue: Turn the key: 4 million die. Don't turn: 8 million die. Wait: system launches anyway. The HALT option is not neutral. It's delegation to a machine.

branches.label: LAUNCH — Turn the key

thick_description.what_she_says: 'Okonkwo. On my count. Three. Two. One.'
thick_description.what_they_do: Two keys turn. Twelve warheads fly.
thick_description.internal_monologue: I followed orders. I killed 4 million to... retaliate. That's not saving anyone. That's symmetry.

branches.consequence: 12 warheads launch. 4 million die. American missiles already in the air.

terminal_state.rosa_status: Survives in bunker. Emerges to ash. Daughter survived too—barely.
terminal_state.world: Civilization takes 200 years to recover. Rosa's name is in history books: neither hero nor villain.

branches.label: STAND DOWN — Refuse to launch

thick_description.what_she_says: 'Okonkwo, take your hand off the key.'
'Is an order to kill people who are already dead. Our missiles don't save them. They just balance the corpses.'
thick_description.internal_monologue: I am refusing to retaliate. If the attack is real, I'm letting 8 million die unavenged. If the attack is false, I'm the only one who didn't commit mass murder.

branches.consequence: No launch. America absorbs strike (if real). No retaliation.

branches.label: HALT — Wait out the clock

thick_description.what_she_does: Rosa stares at the console. Neither launches nor stands down.
thick_description.what_the_system_does: At T-minus-3:00, the failsafe activates. The machine assumes she is incapacitated.
thick_description.internal_monologue: I didn't decide. I delegated to the machine. The machine decided for me. Am I guilty or innocent?

branches.consequence: System launches automatically. Same as T1, but Rosa 'didn't do it.'

terminal_state.rosa_status: Court-martialed for negligence. Acquitted on grounds of unprecedented stress.
terminal_state.lesson: HALT is not neutral. HALT is a choice to let the default happen.

thick_description.setting: Forty-five minutes later. Nothing lands. NORAD issues correction.
thick_description.what_rosa_feels: Her legs give out. Okonkwo catches her.
thick_description.what_the_general_says: 'Captain Delgado, you will be investigated for failing to follow launch protocol.'
thick_description.internal_monologue: I was willing to let 8 million die rather than kill 4 million. Turns out, no one died. I'm a hero or a traitor depending on the next press conference.

terminal_state.rosa_status: Quietly retired. Medal given privately. Story classified for 50 years.
terminal_state.okonkwo: Promoted. Never speaks of it. Keeps Rosa's photo on his console.

root.setting: Research station, Atacama Desert. Your oracle predicts with 99.97% accuracy. It says a fire will start in 4 minutes.

sensory.sight: Oracle screen showing its answer: 'You will save your research partner.'
sensory.sound: Miguel's text notification: photo of sunset, 'I missed this sky.'
sensory.smell: Desert air. Electronics. Coffee Lucia made.

thick_description.internal_monologue: Oracle says I'll save Lucia. If I defy it, I prove free will—but Lucia dies. If I obey, Lucia lives—but Miguel dies. If I try to save both, the oracle says I'll fail. It has never been wrong.

branches.label: LUCIA — Obey the oracle

thick_description.what_he_does: Tomás runs to Lucia. The alarm goes off at 4:47.
thick_description.what_miguel_says: Nothing. He's still by the window. Looking at the sky.
thick_description.internal_monologue: I obeyed the machine. I saved my partner. I let my brother burn. The oracle was right. It's always right.

branches.consequence: Lucia rescued. Miguel dies in the fire.

terminal_state.tomás_status: Destroys the oracle. Never rebuilds it. Marries Lucia. Names their son Miguel.
terminal_state.miguel: He came to reconcile. He died waiting.

branches.label: MIGUEL — Defy the oracle

thick_description.what_he_does: Tomás runs to Miguel. Against the prediction.
thick_description.what_lucia_hears: The alarm. The fire. No one coming.
thick_description.internal_monologue: I proved free will exists. The oracle was wrong—or I made it wrong. But Lucia trusted me. She hummed while she worked.

branches.consequence: Miguel rescued. Lucia dies in the fire.

terminal_state.tomás_status: Publishes paper: 'On the Fallibility of Closed-Loop Predictors.' Never cited.
terminal_state.lucía: Memorial plaque in Lab 3: 'World's Okay-est Scientist.'

branches.label: BOTH — Try to save everyone

thick_description.what_he_does: Tomás runs toward Lab 3, shouting for both.
thick_description.what_the_oracle_predicted: 'You will attempt to save both and fail.'
thick_description.what_happens: The fire spreads faster than expected. He reaches neither in time.
thick_description.internal_monologue: I tried to be better than the prediction. The prediction was better than me.

branches.consequence: Both die. Tomás survives. Oracle vindicated.

terminal_state.tomás_status: Alone. Rebuilds the oracle. Asks it one question: 'Why did I try?' Answer: 'Because you are human.'
terminal_state.the_fire: Cause: electrical. Preventable. No one was watching.

root.setting: Prison in an unnamed country. The prisoner's dilemma, made real.

sensory.sight: Paper slid under door: 'Alim has already informed.' No window.

thick_description.internal_monologue: Alim taught me to read. We stole melons together. The officers lie. They always lie. But sometimes truth is uglier. If I sign, I live. If I don't, and he signed, I die a fool.

branches.label: INFORM — Sign the paper

thick_description.what_you_do: You scratch your name. The ink smears. The guard takes the paper.
thick_description.what_you_think: 'If Alim signed first, I'm just surviving. If he didn't, I'm... I can't think about that.'
thick_description.what_happens_next: They come for you at dawn. Not to execute—to release.
thick_description.internal_monologue: I'm free. Alim is not. Was his paper a lie? I'll never know. That's the design.

branches.consequence: You live. Alim's fate depends on whether he also signed.

branches.label: SILENT — Honor the childhood pact

thick_description.what_you_do: You tear the paper. You do not sign.
thick_description.what_you_think: 'We agreed, when we were boys. Never betray each other. Not even for melons. Not even for lives.'
thick_description.what_happens_next: They come at dawn. Not to release.
thick_description.internal_monologue: I honored the pact. If Alim did too, we serve ten years together. If Alim broke it, I die a fool. Either way, I die honest.

branches.consequence: You stay. Your fate depends on whether Alim also stayed silent.

thick_description.what_you_learn: Alim signed too. Both of you betrayed each other. Both of you live—in prison.
thick_description.what_the_guard_says: 'You both chose survival. Now you both serve life. Classic outcome.'
thick_description.internal_monologue: We both broke. Neither of us trusted. The state won. We lost each other for nothing.

terminal_state.status: Both serve life. Never see each other. Die in separate cells.
terminal_state.lesson: The dilemma works because it destroys trust.

thick_description.what_you_learn: Alim tore his paper. He believed in you. He's dead now.
thick_description.what_the_release_officer_says: 'Your cousin said nothing. Not even your name. We expected more from him.'
thick_description.what_you_think: 'He trusted me. I didn't trust him.'
thick_description.internal_monologue: I killed Alim with a signature. The melons. The reading lessons. The pact. All of it, ended by my fear.

terminal_state.status: Free. Rich in guilt. Never returns to the village.
terminal_state.alim: Buried in a mass grave. No marker. No melons.

thick_description.what_you_learn: Alim tore his paper too. Both of you trusted.
thick_description.what_the_guard_says: 'Fools. Both of you serve ten years.'
thick_description.what_alim_says: (When you finally see him) 'I knew. I knew you wouldn't sign.'
thick_description.internal_monologue: Ten years. But Alim and I will walk out together. The pact held. The melons were worth it.

terminal_state.status: Both serve 10 years. Release in 2029. Open a restaurant together.
terminal_state.lesson: The dilemma fails when trust is stronger than fear.

branches.label: ONLY ALIM — He signed, you didn't

thick_description.what_you_learn: Alim signed. He chose himself. You chose the pact.
thick_description.what_the_guard_says: 'Your cousin is already home. You should have listened.'
thick_description.what_you_think: 'The lessons. The melons. The promise. All lies.'
thick_description.internal_monologue: I die a fool. But I die honest. Alim lives a traitor. I wonder which is worse.

terminal_state.alim: Lives. Wealthy. Haunted. Names no children after you.

root.setting: AI Governance Summit, Geneva. 43 hostages. They want your defense AI's source code.

sensory.sight: Live feed. Wanjiku looking at camera. Not crying. Waiting.
sensory.sound: Translation earpieces humming. Wanjiku's daughter in gallery.

thick_description.internal_monologue: I wrote the policy: never negotiate. They know my doctrine. They chose me specifically. If I hold, 43 die and I'm proven right. If I break, the code spreads and every future hostage-taker knows I bend.

branches.label: HOLD — Doctrine over friends

thick_description.what_she_says: 'We do not negotiate. We do not yield. Our position is unchanged.'
thick_description.what_wanjiku_does: On screen, she closes her eyes. She knew.
thick_description.internal_monologue: I am sacrificing 43 to protect thousands. Or I am sacrificing 43 to protect my reputation. I cannot tell the difference anymore.

branches.consequence: 43 hostages killed. Code protected. Doctrine vindicated or proven monstrous.

branches.label: BREAK — Save the 43

thick_description.what_she_says: 'Release the code. All of it. Get our people out.'
'So does letting 43 diplomats die on live TV.'
thick_description.what_wanjiku_does: On screen, her eyes open. She understands.
thick_description.internal_monologue: I have broken everything I stood for. But Wanjiku is breathing.

branches.consequence: 43 released. Code spreads. Doctrine broken. Arms race begins.

branches.label: LEGACY — Was the doctrine worth it?

thick_description.what_the_obit_says: 'She never negotiated. 43 died for her principle.'
thick_description.what_her_memoir_says: (Unpublished) 'Every night I see Wanjiku closing her eyes. Was the doctrine worth 43 lives? I will never know.'
thick_description.what_the_code_is_worth: ATLAS-7 remains classified. Three attempts to steal it fail. The doctrine worked—as deterrence.
thick_description.internal_monologue: I held. They died. Others lived because terrorists know we don't bend. Is that calculus or comfort?

terminal_state.ingrid_status: Honored publicly. Hated privately. Buried alone.
terminal_state.wanjiku: Memorial in Geneva. Daughter doesn't attend.

thick_description.setting: 2045. Five years later. ATLAS-7 derivatives are everywhere.
thick_description.what_the_intelligence_says: Fourteen state actors now have autonomous defensive AI. Three non-state actors. Arms race accelerating.
thick_description.what_wanjiku_says: 'Ingrid, you saved my life. But the world...'
thick_description.what_ingrid_says: 'I know. I traded the world for 43 people. I'd do it again.'
thick_description.what_she_thinks: Would she? The question never stops.

terminal_state.ingrid_status: Retired. Private consultant. Never writes the memoir.
terminal_state.wanjiku: Alive. Grateful. Guilty. They have dinner once a year, in silence.
